track season in the South will
take place this Saturday evening

the Fifth Regiment .Athletic Association. The meet will be held
in the Fifth Regiment Armory,
which has one of the best indoor
tracks in the East. For several
weeks Mr'. Theodore Kistler, secretary of the games committee, has

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 24, 1921

TRUSTEES TO COMPLETE ALUMNI
DORMITORY FUND
Announcement Made by Dr. Goodnow at Alumni Banquet.
Enthusiastic Meeting at Baltimore Country Club.
F. D. Roosevelt Speaks:
In speaking before the alumni at their annual banquet, held last
Tuesday at the Baltimore Country Club, President Goodnow made the
welcome announcement that the trustees will in all probability complete
the alumni dormitory fund. Money for the purpose will be appro
priated from the bequest of William Bennett Paca, and ground will be
broken before July 1. The fund now totals $215,000, while the cost
of the building will be about $365,000.
Dr. Goodnow also praised the loyalty of the college alumni, whose
influence and interest in its affairs is productive of much good to the
institution.
, F. D. Roosevelt, the principal speaker of the evening, spoke of the
work of college men during the war, and of their part in the future
of the country. Even before this country entered the struggle, he said,
many college alumni were urging preparedness, while they furnished a
large proportion of the leadership and direction once we were in.
It is the duty of college men, Mr. Roosevelt believes, to continue to
exercise this influence in the trying days of reconstruction which face
us. The nation will undoubtedly weather the storm of financial trouble,
but "it is important to remember that no nation can weather a financial
storm if the rest of the world is allowed to go to pot."
Dr. Charles Caspari, '96, of St. Louis, who came on especially for
the dinner, made a plea for continued activity on the part of the Alumni
Association. Now that the dormitory is provided for, there is no
reason why the association should not raise funds for other buildings.
"That is what an alumni association is for." In this view he was supported by George L. Radcliffe and R. Brent Keyser, who felt that the
work should not stop.
Dr. Harvey B. Stone, vice-president of the Varsity Club, made a
statement concerning the work of the Homewood Company, the holding
company for athletic affairs. He believes, he said, that the greatest
need of the University is for a gymnasium. He also announced that
the Varsity Club was considering the establishment of several seholarships as war memorials, to be awarded not solely for scholarship, but
somewhat on the Rhodes plan; that is, for scholarship, character, physical ability and leadership.
Preceding the dinner, the annual election of members of the Alumni
Council was held. The results were as follows: Council representatives, W. S. Symington for Ph.D. group; Dr. G. S. Robinson for
'M.D. group; W. W.Pagon for A.B. group, and C. W. Howard at large.
Executive Committee—W. C. Sehnieisser, H. P. French, K. Singewald,
J. U. Muller and E. H. Miles.
Members of the Class of '96, 24 in number, held a reunion during the
day, and later,visited Annapolis, where they were entertained at luncheon by Governor Ritchie, one of the class. They returned to Baltimore
in time toiattend the banquet.

Speaking before a large gathering of students, alumni and visitors at the exercise last Tuesday
in commemoration of the founding
of the University 45 years ago, Dr.
Frank J. Goodnow, president of
the Johns Hopkins University,
brought out as the main point of
his opening address the fact that
until greater funds are available,
limitation of students will be necessary.
"Where it is necessary that the
number of students be limited,"
said President Goodnow, "the
limitation should be based on
merit, merit as determined by examination, by intelligence tests as
soon as they may be so developed
that we can with confidence rely
upon them, and by record of performance. Above all, we should
not retain a student as to whom
in the light of such facts as we can
safely use we feel certain that he
cannot make good. Democracy in
education may have its place in
the lower schools. Perhaps it is
true that those schools should be
made to fit the student, though of
that there would appear to be
some doubt. Higher education is,
however, organized to prepare for
the professions, the qualifications
of which are definitely fixed.
"Here there is no room, particularly in the crowded conditions we
now face, for the student who does
not either have the ability to justify the necessary expenditure of
money and effort which his training involves, or who is not willing
to make his education the serious
purpose of his life."
Following his address Dr. Goodthe annual
now announced that '
anonymous donor of $5000 for the
furtherance of "art as applied to
science" had again donated the
sum; that James Schouler a
had
former Hopkins lecturer, '
awarded the University $14,000 for
lecture endowment, bringing the
total lecture endowment fund to
$25,000, and the late William Bennett Paca had made the University the residuary legatee of his
estate, with the expression of the
wish that the money be used for
the building fund for the erection
of college buildings at Homewood.
The alumni fund for the memorial dormitory has reached $215,000, Dr. Goodnow announced, and
the work of building would be begun as soon as practicable.

were no more different than those

"DR." LITZ.
Some amount of more or less
disdainful interest was aroused on
the campus last Monday, February
14, by an article appearing in the
issue of the Baltimore Sun of that
date containing an alleged interview with Francis A. Litz, assistant instructor in English at
Hopkins. The sum and substance
of this interview was that "Professor" Litz, as the Sun reportei
titled him, thought the time has
come for the establishment at Hopkins of a course offering instruction in such subjects as dancing, etiquette,"small talk,"thea tricals, etc. Mr. Litz, who was formerly an instructor in several coeducational schools and colleges,
suggested that these courses might
serve as a substitute for purely
academic training for those who
find the present curriculum a bore
and that it might even lead to a
degree, such as "bachelor of society," which would serve to prove
the true "lounge-lizzard" qualities of its possessor.
Mr. Litz concluded by saying
that he was perfectly in earnest
in his proposition, but, according

to a subsequent article appearing
in the Evening Sun of the same
day, the matter was taken as more
or less of a joke by two of the leading educators in the city, namely,
Dr. Goodnow, of Hopkins, and Dr.,
Guth, president of Goucher College. The Hopkins president said
that he thought Mr. Litz was probably only trying to make a joke of
the courses that are from time
to time proposed to the college,
while Dr. Guth, when asked
whether he thought there was any
need for a course in "small talk,"
answered by simply saying that he
thought Mr. Litz was not to be
taken seriously.
Whether Mr. Litz is or is not to
be taken seriously is, of course,
still a question—one which will
probably never be satisfactorily
answered, regardless of its great
importance. Whether it was meant
as? a joke or not, however, it would
seem that Mr. Litz was thoughtless, to say the least, in giving so
much publicity to his views which
have evidently been the cause of
thorough disgust to those interested in the welfare of the university.
If Mr. Litz was entirely serious
in his proposal, why, then as has
been asked by more then one
student, did he not remain at one
of the female colleges, at which he
is said to have acted as instructor,
and "take it out" on the fair "coeds," instead of wishing to inflict
it upon the poor, inoffensive male
at Hopkins? Another suggestion
which has been made is that he
substitute "small talk" for "public sleeping I," the only class, according to him, with which he has
not been able to get along perfectly.
If, on the other hand, the worthy
instructor was attempting to be
"funny" at the expense of the university and its courses, he has at
the same time attempted by ridicule to place the college in a rather
unfavorable light in the eyes of the
public.
With the entire student-body
and faculty making a supreme effort to place Hopkins on a firm
foundation alongside of the other
leading institutions of the country,
it would seem rather inconsiderate
of Mr. Litz to attempt to injure
its dignity by advancing such ideas
as his on the back page of one of
the city's leading dailies.

In speaking before the assembly
of last week Dean Late made
an interesting statement on what
he considers will be the future of
the American college. He said
that the college is changing and
will change as much in the future
as in the past; at present the
standards are too lx and too
many men that are in coJege take

Dean deprecated the great number

WORK ON PLAY IN FINAL STAGE.

The Dramatic Club has reached
the final stage of preparation for
the play since the actors have
all completed the memorizing of
their lines. All that now remains
is the process of polishing up the
performance of the play.
Tickets for the performance may
be procured now at the Barn, and
after February 25 at Albaugh's
Ticket Office and at the Lyric. The
prices range from 50 cents to V.
"Arms and the Man," the play
by Bernard Shaw, will be produced
on March 11, and it is hoped that
everyone will back it up, since the
club has devoted much time and
trouble and no little expense to its
success.
The scenery, designed by Mr.
Badillo, is now well under way.
It consists of three sets. The construction of the "props," too, is
moving forward very rapidly.
The cast is small but capable.
Joseph Moran, as Raina, and Bartus Trew, as Sergius, are the leading characters.
"Arms and the Man" is a very
delightful satire on Balkan life
and seems Well suited to the cast
selected.

BASKET-BALL TEAM TWICE
DEFEATED

HOPKINS SWIMMERS
CLOSE MEET

Both Drexel and Lehigh Roll Up Large
Scores When Visited by Hopkins
Courtmen. Final Counts 50 to 27
and 36 to 16. Wilkinson Stitrs for
Hopkins.

The Varsity basket-ball team
suffered defeat in both games of
their Northern trip last week.
In the first, the game with
Drexel, on Friday night, the visiting quint suffered defeat by a 50-27
score. Hopkins was greatly handicapped by the undersized floor,
which measured but 36 feet, as
measured by the managers of the
two teams. The playing was a bit
rough, several players finally being ejected for personal fouls.
In the opening minutes of the
game Hopkins erred in endeavoring to play the man and neglecting the ball. As a result, a good
lead was quickly mounted against
them. Following a rally in the latter part of the first period, the
score evened up to 13-10, but the
half finally ended 33-14.
The home team had things
pretty much its own way in the
second half, the exceptional work
of Weinberger causing the final
score.
According to Coach McAvoy,
Drexel played her best game of
the season, taking advantage of all
the breaks.
The game with Lehigh was a different matter.: Their team put
up a far superior brand of basketball, Hopkins players proving too
inexperienced to cope with them.
Their floorwork and shooting was
accurate and brilliant, marked by
several thrilling shots and pushing the final score up to 36-16.
Captain Donovan was the individual star, although Lingle, the"
other forward, rivaled him for
honors, each scoring four field
goals.
Hopkins, as usual, played its
best in the first half, scoring nine
points to its opponents' fourteen.
Wilkinson, who substituted for
Owings in the second half, played
a flashy game for the short time
he played.
Cashell was not up to his usual
standard in the matter of shooting
fouls, caging but four out of thirteen attempts. Owings showed
improvement in this line, being
successful twice out of three tries.
Following the game the team
was royally entertained by their
late opponents at Moose Hall.
